occurrences.line_text: A gentle Faulcon sitting on an hill,
More light then Culuer in the Faulcons fist.
And eke the Doue sate by the Faulcons side,
As when a cast of Faulcons make their flight
Fly like a flocke of doues before a Faulcons vew.
Or thine the fault, or mine the error is,
Here endlesse penance for one fault I pay,
That tree through one mans fault hath doen vs all to dy.
Him ill beseemes, anothers fault to name,
That is each thing, by which the eyes may fault:
The cause to weet, and fault to remedy;
For not thy fault, but secret powre vnseene,
Let not her fault your sweet affections marre,
He cast to punish for his hainous fault;
Ne all are shamed by the fault of one;
For fault of few that haue abusd the same.
Yet thou false Squire his fault shalt deare aby,
Yet found no fault, but that the Hag did scold
And grieued sore, that through his fault she had
Tooke in foule scorne, that I such fault did find,
Me seemes, that him befell by his owne fault:
Yet since it was his fortune, not his fault,
To iustifie thy fault gainst me in equall fight.
The heauens of their fortunes fault accuse,
Or fault of men, he broke his yron chaine,
And though they faultie were, yet well he wayd,
The faultie soules from thence brought to his heauenly bowre.
But if your selfe, Sir knight, ye faultie find,
Or faultie thoughts continewd, as was fit;
Her faultie Handmayd, which that bale did breede,
Ne naturall affection faultlesse blame,
To faire accordaunce, and both faults to shade,
Our faulty weaknesse, and your matchlesse might:
Right true: but faulty men vse oftentimes
Gan him salute, and fowle vpbrayd with faulty blame.
This fround, that faund, the third for shame did blush,
A troupe of Faunes and Satyres far away
Dan Faunus chaunst to meet her by the way,
Of sundry shapes, yet all ill fauored:
Of her fond fauorites so nam'd amis:
So be, O Queene, you equall fauour showe.
Who glad to gain such fauour, gan deuise,
Was out of Dianes fauour, as it then befell.
If lesse, then that I feare, more fauour I haue found.
Did seeme to laugh on me, and fauour mine intent.
In hope to win more fauour with his mate,
Great fauour I thee graunt, for aunswere thus to stay.
But sith thou hast found fauour in mine eye,
And in her fauour high be reckoned,
They her besought of fauour speciall,
And found such fauour in their louing hartes,
And soueraine fauour towards chastity,
But when with feare, nor fauour, nor with all
Yet so much fauour she to him hath hight,
Thenceforth I found more fauour at her hand,
To laugh at me, and fauour my pretence,
She then in recompence of that great fauour,
By all the meanes she might, to curry fauour
From seeking fauour, where it doth abound;
In case she might finde fauour in his eye,
But through high heauens grace, which fauour not
Finde fauour to be lodged there for that same night.
The fauour of Belphebe, (as ye heard)
Let me therefore this fauour for him finde,
Yet heauens them selues, that fauour feeble rights,
Good will and fauour. So it surely wrought
Of courtly fauour, fed with light report,
And daily more her fauour to augment;
To graunt him fauour, or afford him loue.
Some shew of fauour, by him gracing small,
The fauourable heauens did not enuy,
How to aduaunce with fauourable hands,
The heauens so fauourable were and free,
And whilest him fortune fauourd, faire did thriue
And eke her face ill fauourd, full of wrinckles old.
Of griesly hew, and fowle ill fauour'd sight;
Shame most ill fauourd, bestiall, and blind:
Whilest Fortune fauourd her successe in fight,
When as two old ill fauour'd Hags he met,
A loathly, wrinckled hag, ill fauoured, old,
Who whiles good fortune fauoured her might,
A foule ill fauoured foster, I haue seene;
But he was foule, ill fauoured, and grim,
Was fauoured, and to her grace commmended.
To make them louely or well fauoured show,
The sonnes of Day he fauoureth, I see,
Heauen doth to me enuy, and fortune fauourlesse.
The many fauours I with thee haue found,
With which she sprinckled fauours manifold,
And such fond fauours sparingly dispenst:
And him receiu'd againe to former fauours state.
For his friends sake her offred fauours scorne,
That she knew not his fauours likelynesse,
But when she saw, through that small fauours gaine,
Do kisse her feete, and fawne on her with count'nance faine.
And when her listed, she could fawne and flatter;
Sometime the fawne I practise from the Doe,
Her fawning loue with foule disdainefull spight
And lickt her lilly hands with fawning tong,
With fawning wordes he courted her a while,
A wicked Spright yfraught with fawning guile,
Despysde, and all the fawning of the flatterer.
Came to her creeping like a fawning hound,
Of grieuous mischiefes, which a wicked Fay
Therefore a Fay he her according hight,
But that he by an Elfe was gotten of a Fay.
Their mother was a Fay, and had the skill
To whom fierce Atropos, Bold Fay, that durst
They graunted it; and then that carefull Fay
Therefore this Fay I hold but fond and vaine,
And well instructed by the Fay her mother,
That neither hath religion nor fay,
He wonneth in the land of Fayeree,
Her many deemd to haue beene of the Fayes,
But she as Fayes are wont, in priuie place
Some thought that some enchantment faygned it;
Oft he re'nforst, and oft his forces fayld,
His owne good sword Morddure, that neuer fayld
Benumbd so inly, that her wits nigh fayld,
So liuely and so like, that liuing sence it fayld.
And new occasion fayld her more to find,
That fayld the trust, which she in him had plast,
And had he not bene held, he nought had fayld of it.
For what their speares had fayld of their pretence.
So when he saw his flatt'ring arts to fayle,
Of which he now did very litle fayle,
Then if all fayle, we will by force it win,
But now my teme begins to faint and fayle,
Where finding that the breath gan him to fayle,
Till feeling life to fayle, it fell, and deadly slept.
It shall not fayle, when so ye shall it need.
And if I hap to fayle, you shall recure my right.
Abate, and panting breath begin to fayle,
And former liuelod fayle, she left me quight,
So did deceipt the selfe deceiuer fayle,
And if all fayle, yet farewell open field:
His hart gan fayle, albe he saw them all asleepe.
Which fayled oft through faint and feeble plight:
Fayles of her souse, and passing by doth hurt no more.
At last when fayling breath began to faint,
Which fayling he gan fiercely her pursew.
Fro[m] her own worship, they her Asse would worship fayn.
Some feard, and fled; some feard and well it faynd;
And faynd to wash themselues incessantly;
Dissembled faire, and faynd to ouersee.
What euer foe had wrought, or frend had faynd,
That much they faynd to know, who she mote bee;
Faynd to alight, something amisse to mend;
She fayn'd to count the time againe anew,
One time, when he his weapon faynd to shift,
Wherein her face she often vewed fayne,
Whom greatest Princes court would welcome fayne;
That they were fayne to let him scape away,
Which message when Grantorto heard, full fayne
The noble ympe of such new seruice fayne,
Her fayned Paramour, her forced guest,
Become of fayned friendship which they vow'd afore.
Of fayned loue, they chaunst to ouertake
And fayned still her former angry mood,
Farre from all fraud, or fayned blandishment;
For comming to this knight, she purpose fayned,
With fayned colours shading a true case:
That vnder shew oftimes of fayned semblance,
Ye will them all but fayned showes esteeme,
Yet were her words and lookes but false and fayned,
Of few greene turfes an altar soone they fayned,
And faynes to weaue false tales and leasings bad,
As fayning choler, which was turn'd to cold:
Some fearing fraud, some fraudulently fayning,
As a bad Nurse, which fayning to receiue
To whom the Prince, him fayning to embase,
She was dismayd, or faynted through affright,
fayre Vna is releast:
The cause was this: one day when Phoebe fayre
Of knighthood trew, and is of fayre
Who had to wife Dame Mertia the fayre,
Where when she had espyde that mirrhour fayre,
That now with thousand starres was decked fayre;
He turnd him selfe into a Dolphin fayre;
Fayre Britomart saues Amoret,
Whom she requir'd, that first fayre Amoret
And eke fayre Amoret now freed from feare,
So fayre a spoyle, to make you ioyous meriment?
Cambelloes sister was fayre Canacee,
Fayre Canacee vpon a stately stage
For all afore that seemed fayre and bright,
Ne ought on earth that louely is and fayre,
A beuie of fayre damzels close did lye,
Left a fayre Ladie languishing in payne:
The spreading Lee, that like an Island fayre
And shouldred hath the Bull, which fayre Europa bore.
With a fayre loue, whose losse I now do rew,
Fayre Florimell, into the common hall,
But some fayre Franion, fit for such a fere,
Bold Marinell with Florimell the fayre,
And bringing light into the heauens fayre,
Of fayre Irenaes cause with him in single fight.
For fayre Irena, whom they loued deare.
Faire gentle swayne, and yet as stout as fayre,
A saluage man matcht with a Ladie fayre,
Yet since thy life vnto this Ladie fayre
Fayre Mirabellaes punishment
Fayre Mirabella was her name, whereby
and loues fayre Pastorell;
Yet seem'd the soyle both fayre and frutefull eft,
And soothly sure she was full fayre of face,
And the fayre mayd the table ta'ne away,
When he the loue of fayre Oenone sought,
Fayre Pastorell, who with the selfe same wound
Fayre Pastorella by great hap
Where him Blandina fayrely entertayned,
He, whether mine seem'd fayrer in his eye,
No fayrer conquest, then that with goodwill is gayned.
Amongst them all growes not a fayrer flowre,
For sure the fayrest Florimell him seemed,
Too foolish Paridell, that fayrest floure
That fayrest Florimell was present there in place.
Fayrest of faire, that fairenesse doest excell,
And of them all she that is fayrest found,
The fayrest Ladie was adiudgd for Paramore.
Of beauties praise, and yeeld the fayrest her due fee.
Graunted to her, as to the fayrest Dame.
First in the midst to set that fayrest Dame,
The fayrest Ladie reft, and euer since withheld.
Doest fayrest shine, and most adorne thy place,
That same was fayrest Amoret in place,
And then to him came fayrest Florimell,
Presented to the fayrest Florimell;
The fayrest kyne aliue, but of the fiercest kynd.
The fayrest Pastorella her by name did hight.
The father of the fayrest Pastorell,
By which home came the fayrest Pastorell,
The fayrest Ladie then of all that liuing were.
The Fayrie glad to gaine his libertie,
Clarin (sayd she) thou seest yond Fayry Knight,
By this false faytor, who vnworthy ware
Leaue faytor quickely that misgotten weft
To Philemon, false faytour Philemon
And read, where I that faytour false may find.
Defeated had the other faytour quight,
Being oppressed by that faytour bold,
So ought all faytours, that true knighthood shame,
Or through alleageance and fast fealtie,
And swore to him true fealtie for aye.
Their king, and swore him fealty to win or loose.
Shall yield him selfe his liegeman, and sweare fealty.
Made them sweare fealty to Artegall.
Through fear and wonder, that he nought could say,
For fear through want of words her excellence to marre.
For fear the cruell Feends should thee vnwares deuowre.
He feard not once him selfe to be in need,
Some feard, and fled; some feard and well it faynd;
Some feard, and fled; some feard and well it faynd;
Besides he feard her wrath, and threatned shot
But feard to wander in that wastfull mist,
Yet nought they feard, but past on hardily,
Nought feard their force, that fortilage to win,
Ne euill thing she fear'd, ne euill thing she ment.
Yet she no lesse the knight feard, then that villein rude.
And shund dishonor, which as death she feard:
But feard each shadow mouing to and fro,
That much she feard his mind would grow to some excesse.
His will she feard; for him she surely thought
But then he fear'd his mothers former charge
He fear'd least they with shame would him pursew.
Nought fear'd the childe his lookes, ne yet his threats,
As if the onely sound thereof she feard.
On which he safety hopes, that earst feard to be lost.
Groning full deadly, all with troublous feare,
Or wonted feare of doing ought amis,
That of himselfe he oft for feare would quake,
Still flying from his thoughts and gealous feare;
Much rueth me; but now put feare apart,
But fly, ah fly far hence away, for feare
Full of sad feare and ghastly dreriment,
Then turning to his Lady, dead with feare her found.
Her seeming dead he found with feigned feare,
And oft her kist. At length all passed feare,
With suddaine feare her pitcher downe she threw,
With quaking hands, and other signs of feare:
Nigh dead with feare, and faint astonishment,
But now for feare her beads she did forget.
And so forth told the story of her feare:
Loth was that other, and did faint through feare,
And had his staggering steede not shrunke for feare,
To get, and nightly feare to lose his owne,
For needlesse feare did neuer vantage none,
O but I feare the fickle freakes (quoth shee)
And th'vnacquainted light began to feare:
And trembling yet through feare of former hate;
And euery tender part for feare does shake:
With chaunge of feare, to see the Lyon looke so grim.
To comfort her, and feare to put away,
But still twixt feare and hope amazd does sit,
And fly away for feare of fowle disgrace:
To banish cowardize and bastard feare;
That euery beast for feare of him did fly and quake.
And lull in rugged armes, withouten childish feare.
To feare his force: and then his courage haught
For feare as seemd, or for some feigned losse;
If lesse, then that I feare, more fauour I haue found.
Themselues, for feare into his iawes to fall,
But trembling feare did feele in euery vaine;
And trembling with strange feare, did like an earthquake show.
The stedfast globe of earth, as it for feare did quake.
But th'onely good, that growes of passed feare,
As if his feare still followed him behind;
Feare to his first amazment, staring wide
But through his boldnesse rather feare did reach,
Feare nought: (quoth he) no daunger now is nye?
Fled fast away, halfe dead with dying feare:
But th'other forst him stay, and comforted in feare.
That makes fraile flesh to feare the bitter waue?
Feare, sicknesse, age, losse, labour, sorrow, strife,
For feare of many foes: but when they knockt,
Whose face he made, all beasts to feare, and gaue
That sight thereof bred cold congealed feare:
That made the Redcrosse knight nigh quake for feare,
In feare to lose his weapon in his paw,
He woxe dismayd, and gan his fate to feare;
The sight with idle feare did them dismay,
Halfe dead through feare, her litle babe reuyld,
For feare of euill fates, but burnen euer bright.
Through inward feare, and seeming pale and faint
With stony feare of that rude rustick mate,
Yet cold through feare, and old conceiued dreads;
And ayme at him, fell flat to ground for feare,
If where those knights for feare of dew vengeaunce
In which they shrowd the[m]selues from causelesse feare;
Yet feare them followes still, where so they beene,
For feare through want of skill her beautie to disgrace?
Both feare and hope he in her face did find,
For who can tell (and sure I feare it ill)
Dismay with feare, or cause one foot to flie,
But now for feare of worse, that may betide,
Feare gaue her wings, and rage enforst my flight;
For feare of further harme, I counsell thee,
Ne care, ne feare I, how the wind do blow,
And trembling Feare still to and fro did fly,
For feare least Force or Fraud should vnaware
Does shew to him, that walkes in feare and sad affright.
Which when his german saw, the stony feare
You to molest, or other ill to feare
How shall fraile pen, with feare disparaged,
The faire Sabrina almost dead with feare,
Which th'Infants tutors gathering to feare,
So fowle and vgly, that exceeding feare
His light-foot beast, fled fast away for feare:
That all the seas for feare do seeme away to fly.
His whirling charet, for exceeding feare:
Such as Dame Nature selfe mote feare to see,
Which seem'd to fly for feare, them to behold:
Feare nought, (then said the Palmer well auiz'd;)
About them flew, and fild their sayles with feare:
In stead of fraying, they them selues did feare,
For feare of waking him, his lips bedewd,
Fled all away for feare of fowler shame.
Which when his Palmer saw, he gan to feare
And eke through feare as white as whales bone:
For feare least her vnwares she should abrayd,
Through suddein feare and ghastly drerihed,
And striuing, fit to make, I feare do marre:
Aye me, how much I feare, least loue it bee;
And euer her importund, not to feare
That when old Glauce saw, for feare least blame
For thy great care she tooke, and greater feare,
So greatly his commaundement they feare,
The warlike Mertians for feare to quake:
Of natiue courage, that his foes shall feare,
Now blazed was, and feare did all inuade,
The which his mother seeing, gan to feare
For she of womans force did feare no harme;
So deepe the deadly feare of that foule swaine
Doubleth her haste for feare to be for-hent,
Yet former feare of being fowly shent,
And light doe shonne, for feare of being shent:
Carried away with wings of speedy feare.
Which seeing faire Belphoebe, gan to feare,
And so had left them languishing twixt hope and feare.
And from Prince Arthur fled with wings of idle feare.
So fled faire Florimell from her vaine feare,
At last turning her feare to foolish wrath,
For feare of mischiefe, which she did forecast
Was greatly woe begon, and gan to feare,
His nimble feet to her conceiued feare,
Thereto feare gaue her wings, and neede her courage taught.
Full of sad feare, and doubtfull agony,
Then trembling yet through feare, the Squire bespake,
Or else for feare of shame and fowle disgrace.
Against the silly clowne, who dead through feare,
Who seem'd for feare to quake in euery lim,
For shame, but more for feare of his grim sight,
She thought, but chaung'd from one to other feare;
Bidding her feare no more her foeman vilde,
But when with feare, nor fauour, nor with all
Right sore I feare, least with vnworthy blames
And welcomde more for feare, then charitee;
That all men feare to tempt his billowes strong,
He fled for feare of that he had misdonne,
Fond is the feare, that findes no remedie;
The louing couple need no reskew feare,
He fainted, and was almost dead with feare,
In drery darkenesse, and continuall feare
Vntroubled of vile feare, or bitter fell.
It was not Satyrane, whom he did feare,
Out of her thraldome and continuall feare?
That cruell element, which all things feare,
Trembling through feare, least down he fallen should,
Yet nould she d'off her weary armes, for feare
Next him was Feare, all arm'd from top to toe,
But walkt each where, for feare of hid mischaunce,
With her owne trusty Squire, both full of feare,
From her high spirit chase imperious feare,
Thereto her feare was made so much the greater
And eke fayre Amoret now freed from feare,
Then tell (quoth Blandamour) and feare no blame,
Was dead with feare, nathlesse as neede required,
As one in feare the Stygian gods t'offend,
And secret feare, to see their fatall fine,
And louely haulst from feare of treason free,
Whether through foundring or through sodein feare
Yet in his soundest sleepe, his dayly feare
His powrelesse arme benumbd with secret feare
And turning his feare to faint deuotion,
That all his gealous feare he false had found,
For sudden ioy, and secret feare withall,
Ne thenceforth feare the thing that hethertoo
But Scudamour whose hart twixt doubtfull feare
I her preseru'd from perill and from feare,
His hart was thrild with point of deadly feare;
The feare whereof seem'd much her to affray:
And makes her feare a spur to hast her flight:
Pursuing that faire Lady full of feare;
Now freed from feare and danger of that dismall wight.
Yet trembling euery ioynt through former feare;
Himselfe by them on foot, to succour them from feare.
Saw comming home; all voide of doubtfull feare,
Exchanged out of one into an other feare.
Feare of her safety did her not constraine,
But now in feare of shame she more did stond,
But cause of feare sure had she none at all
As if some proued perill he did feare,
For feare of harme, that might lie hidden there;
Stout Theseus, and Pirithous his feare;
That being free from feare and gealosye,
Thee goddesse, thee the winds, the clouds doe feare,
As if some blame of euill she did feare,
Tho shaking off all doubt and shamefast feare,
Mine eye was fixt, for feare of her offence:
For feare of perill, which to him mote fall,
For feare she should of lightnesse be detected:
That makes me feare in time he will vs quite forsake.
That euen wilde beasts did feare his awfull sight,
And fain'd to fly for feare of being thrall;
As rated Spaniell takes his burden vp for feare.
The fortune of her life long time did feare.
That makes all men for feare that passage for to shonne.
And filled all the house with feare and great vprore.
And eke their dame halfe dead did hide her self for feare.
And thus vnto him spake, without regard or feare;
And broke his sword, for feare of further harmes,
For feare her mistresse shold haue knowledge gayned,
And secretly afflict with iealous feare,
In minde he grew, for feare least by that art
They all were fled for feare, but whether, nether kond.
Free Samient from feare:
Carried with wings of feare, like fowle aghast,
To saue her from her feare, and him from force to let.
But th'onely feare, that was before their vew;
As they were follow'd of their former feare.
And tost the Paynim, without feare or awe;
To banish feare, and with Sardonian smyle
Warning him hold it fast, for feare of slights.
Nor vndertake the same, for cowheard feare,
Durst not abide, but fled away for feare,
He gan to burne in rage, and friese in feare,
By those, which earst did fly away for feare
And new life to her lent, in midst of deadly feare.
Of great defence to ward the deadly feare,
As if he would haue daunted him with feare,
Did set vppon vs flying both for feare:
Ne would he spare for pitty, nor refraine for feare.
To you I will not feare it to relate.
Faire Emiline, conceiuing then great feare
And neuer to be recreant, for feare
Most pensiue man, through feare, what of his childe became.
Since first he saw her, and did free from feare
He quite forsooke, and fled himselfe away for feare.
But the wyld man, contrarie to her feare,
Which had them freed from that deadly feare,
As one that had no life him left through former feare.
And crime to crime, by this thy cowheard feare.
For else his feare could not be satisfyde.
For feare of wetting them before their bed;
They that haue much, feare much to loose thereby,
Through cowherd feare he fled away as fast,
Who scarcely yet from former feare exempted,
And yet his feare did follow him behynd:
Hath wrought this wicked deed: doe feare away, and tell.
But he, whose hart through feare was late fordonne,
